Award.AwardTitle: The CIRTL Network: 25 Research Universities Preparing a National Faculty to Advance STEM Undergraduate Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Center for the Integration of Research, Teaching, and Learning (CIRTL) began in 2002 with a grant from the National Science Foundation. Its mission is to broaden and enrich graduate education and post-doctoral preparation in order to develop a national STEM faculty with the capability and commitment to implement and improve effective teaching practices for the learning of all students. The first decade of operation of CIRTL has demonstrated that research universities can effectively prepare future faculty to be both productive researchers and excellent, knowledgeable teachers. CIRTL has developed, implemented, and evaluated successful strategies based on three core ideas: Teaching as Research, learning communities, and learning-through-diversity. In 2011, 1500 future faculty across STEM participated in the learning communities of the six research universities that comprise the prototype CIRTL Network. CIRTL evaluations and associated research on efforts to prepare future faculty indicate that future STEM faculty in such learning communities can effectively use and advance high impact teaching and learning practices and continue to do so once they are hired as new members of the faculty.
In Fall 2011 the CIRTL Network expanded to include 25 diverse research universities; together these universities produce 26% of the STEM Ph.D.s in the United States. These partners are collaborating to establish interdisciplinary learning communities at all 25 universities that can demonstrably prepare future faculty who use and improve best practices in undergraduate education. Common features of the proposed learning communities include teaching-as-research experiences, mentor training, post-doctoral preparation in teaching and learning, use of CIRTL core ideas as a unifying framework for new and existing programs, conceptual strengthening of teaching assistant programs, and facilitation of participation from underrepresented groups. As part of this scale-up a cross-Network learning community is being developed to engage the diversity and expertise of all 25 universities for teaching, mentoring, shared learning, scholarly exploration, and cross-disciplinary collaboration of future faculty.
CIRTL is also engaged in efforts to become a sustainable community. It is engaged in piloting and studying organizational, administrative, and financial structures, examining promising developments in information technology and evaluation methods that support an institutionalized CIRTL Network that is scalable to larger numbers of universities in the future. The CIRTL learning communities in the 25 member universities are expected to educate 7,000 graduate students and post-doctoral fellows each year, of whom 2,200 are estimated to complete their doctoral work annually. This yield is comparable to 25% of the current national production rate of STEM faculty 6 years out of graduate school.
Through national CIRTL Forums, web sites, publications, presentations across STEM disciplines, and collaborations with STEM disciplinary societies and national higher education organizations, the CIRTL Network will impact graduate education in universities beyond the Network. The CIRTL Network Is likely to grow in number. A significant number of additional research universities have expressed interest in joining the network.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Graduate students and post-doctoral fellows at research universities will shape the future of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) undergraduate education in the United States. These future faculty trained at research universities flow into the STEM faculties of 4400 research universities, comprehensive universities, liberal arts colleges, and community and tribal colleges. The Center for the Integration of Research, Teaching, and Learning (CIRTL) uses graduate education and post-doctoral preparation as the leverage point to develop a national faculty with the capability and commitment to implement and improve effective teaching practices for the STEM learning of all students.

Intellectual Merit. CIRTL has established that research universities can and will prepare STEM  future faculty to be both leading researchers and excellent teachers. CIRTL has developed, implemented, and evaluated successful strategies based on three core ideas: teaching-as-research, learning communities, and learning-through-diversity. At the completion of this grant, the CIRTL Network had grown from six universities to 40 universities, which together produce one third of the STEM Ph.D.'s in the United States.

Each partner university has established and evaluated an interdisciplinary learning community on their campus that prepares future faculty to use and improve best practices in undergraduate education. All of the learning communities use the CIRTL core ideas as a unifying framework for new and adapted programs in teaching and learning, including teaching-as-research experiences, research mentor training, post-doctoral preparation, programs aimed at strengthening teaching assistant training, and programs that prepare future faculty to increase the success of students from underrepresented groups.

In the last year of this grant (academic year 2017-18), the CIRTL Network provided local teaching and learning opportunities for 4750 future faculty participants.  The local learning communities throughout the Network produced 2459 CIRTL Associates and 298 CIRTL Practitioners and Scholars. In the CIRTL learning outcomes framework, Associates "know," Practitioners "do," and Scholars "advance and disseminate." The CIRTL Network standard operations are ongoing and independent of external funding, continuing forward this annual impact on the national STEM faculty.

The CIRTL Network also expanded and evaluated the Cross-Network Learning Community (CNLC), which is designed to engage the diversity and expertise of all 40 universities for teaching, mentoring, shared learning, scholarly exploration, and cross-disciplinary collaboration of STEM future faculty.  During the 2017-18 academic year, the CNLC provided 12 online courses, 17 workshops (a one-, two-, or three-session format with pre- and post-work), CIRTLCast series, presentation sessions by Teaching-as-Research interns, and other drop-in events. This programming also models for future faculty how to incorporate evidence-based, active and inclusive learning techniques into synchronous, online learning environments. In addition, the Network hosted 7 in-person regional teaching institutes and one in-depth multi-day online institute. In total, during the 2017-2018 academic year the CNLC hosted more than 1,200 attendees from across and beyond the Network. Finally, 360 individuals completed the 2  CIRTL Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) during this year, many of whom also participated in the 42 MOOC Supported Learning Communities formed nationally and internationally.

CIRTL has done extensive research on the development of future faculty and on the evolution of the CIRTL Network. This grant produced six research briefs (the work in most of which is published): Brief 1: Building Successful Teaching Development Programs for Future Faculty; Brief 2: CIRTL Delphi Study: Key Items for Developing and Supporting Local Learning Communities; Brief 3: The Variability of High-Engagement Teaching-as-Research Programs; Brief 4: The Impact of High-Engagement Teaching-as-Research Programs; Brief 5: The Key Role of Institutional Representatives in Networks; Brief 6: The Impact of the CIRTL Network on Member Campuses. (https://www.cirtl.net/resources/collections/5)

Broader Impact. In addition to the nation's STEM future faculty prepared in the CIRTL Network, CIRTL expanded its role as a focal point of the national conversation on the preparation of STEM faculty. Through national CIRTL Forums, web sites, publications, presentations across STEM disciplines, and collaborations with STEM disciplinary societies and national higher education organizations, the CIRTL Network impacts graduate education in universities beyond the Network. Finally, our research and evaluation of the CIRTL Network informed the growth of other teaching and learning initiatives seeking national transformation.

As the CIRTL Network continues on and grows, the goal is to provide to every undergraduate institution STEM faculty who enable all students to learn effectively and thereby achieve STEM literacy, whose teaching enhances recruitment into STEM careers, and whose leadership ensures the continued advancement of STEM education.
